docs.lead_paragraph: Elderly and disabled members of Medicare H.M.O.'s used nearly 50 percent more of their own money on average for medical care in 2001 than they did three years ago, health care researchers said yesterday. The increase was even steeper for those in poor health, according to a new study by Marsha Gold and Lori Achman of Mathematica Policy Research, a nonprofit, nonpartisan research center in Washington. The study was sponsored by The Commonwealth Fund in New York.

headline.main: Personal Costs for Medicare H.M.O.'s Rise

docs.abstract: Researchers with Mathematica Policy Research report that elderly and disabled members of Medicare HMO's use nearly 50 percent more of their own money on average for medical care in 2001 than they did three years ago and that increase was even steeper for those in poor health; warn that rapidly rising costs will cause people to think twice about value of these health plans; Thomas Scully, administrator of federal Center for Medicare and Medicaid Services, says higher costs are predictable after five years of 2 percent increases in government reimbursements while costs borne by health plans were rising at close to double-digit rate (M)
docs.snippet: Elderly and disabled members of Medicare H.M.O.'s used nearly 50 percent more of their own money on average for medical care in 2001  than they did three years ago, health care researchers said yesterday.     The increase was even steeper for those...

docs.lead_paragraph: When philanthropic giving rose sharply after the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11, many people feared that such giving would divert money from charities. But those fears have largely proven unfounded -- at least for big, name-brand nonprofit organizations. But small neighborhood nonprofits, which provide much of the social service and community development in the city, are struggling, even as the economy gets worse and demand for their services rises.

headline.main: With Larger Charities Faring Well, Neighborhood Nonprofits Struggle

docs.abstract: Small neighborhood nonprofit social services organizations in New York City are struggling financially as economy worsens and demand for their services grows; such groups typically rely on government contracts and fees from services they provide, supplemented by foundation grants and small contributions; lack diverse income sources and experienced fund-raising operations of larger, better-known charities; photo (M)
docs.snippet: When philanthropic giving rose sharply after the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11, many people feared that such giving would divert money from charities. But those fears have largely proven unfounded -- at least for big, name-brand nonprofit...

docs.lead_paragraph: Cantor Fitzgerald, which lost 658 people in the Sept. 11 attacks , reported unexpectedly strong fourth-quarter earnings yesterday for eSpeed, its publicly traded electronic trading unit, and announced that it would share $4.9 million of its own fourth-quarter profits with the families of the employees killed in the attacks. The payment is the first installment in Cantor's previously announced plan to give the families 25 percent of its profits over the next five years, or $100,000 for each family, whichever is greater.

headline.main: $4.9 Million Of Cantor Net To Be Shared By Survivors

docs.abstract: Cantor Fitzgerald, which lost 658 people in Sept 11 terrorist attacks, reports unexpectedly strong fourth-quarter earnings for eSpeed, its publicly traded electronic trading unit, and announces that it will share $4.9 million of its fourth-quarter profits with families of employees killed in attacks; payment is first installment in Cantor's previously announced plan to give families 25 percent of its profits over next five years, or $100,000 for each family, which ever is greater; chairman Howard W Lutnick comments; eSpeed reports fourth-quarter net income of $7.8 million and net operating income of $4.5 million; company lost $5.2 in period year ago, on both net and operating basis; revenue for quarter rose 4.5 percent, to $28.1 million from year earlier (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Kansas state insurance commissioner rejected the proposed acquisition of Blue Cross-Blue Shield of Kansas, the state's largest health insurer, by an Indiana company yesterday, saying it would raise consumer premiums too much. Blue Cross policyholders approved the $321 million buyout by the Indianapolis-based Anthem Insurance Companies last month. ''It would cost Kansas businesses, small employers, and families millions of dollars,'' the commissioner, Kathleen Sebelius, said. Outside counsel and lawyers for the insurance department told Ms. Sebelius in documents filed two weeks ago that if the deal went ahead, premiums would have to increase $248 million over the next five years to meet Anthem's profit margins. Anthem and Blue Cross disputed those conclusions. Anthem officials said Blue Cross subscribers would not see major coverage differences.

headline.main: BLUE CROSS TAKEOVER REJECTED BY KANSAS COMMISSIONER

docs.abstract: Kansas State Insurance Comr Kathleen Sebelius rejects proposed acquisition of Blue Cross-Blue Shield of Kansas, state's largest health insurer, by Indianapolis-based Anthem Insurance Companies for $321 million; says takeover would raise consumer premiums too much (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: The State of Texas sued PacifiCare of Texas Inc. yesterday, claiming slow payments from the health maintenance organization helped force three Texas health care providers into bankruptcy. The lawsuit, filed in Austin, says that PacifiCare failed to properly monitor its delegated networks, organizations that contract with PacifiCare to help provide health care to the H.M.O.'s members. The delegated networks, and in some cases PacifiCare itself, failed to pay health care providers or did not pay them in a timely manner, as Texas law requires, said John Cornyn, the attorney general. Pacific Health Systems Inc. of Santa Ana, Calif., Pacificare's parent company, did not return a phone call seeking comment.

headline.main: TEXAS SUES PACIFICARE, AN H.M.O., OVER PAYMENTS

docs.abstract: State of Texas sues PacifiCare of Texas Inc, claiming slow payments from health maintenance organization helped forced three Texas health care providers into bankruptcy; PacifiCare's parent company is Pacific Health Systems Inc (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: President Bush today outlined a $300 billion, 10-year health care plan that he said would overhaul Medicare, offer a discount card for the elderly to buy prescription drugs and ban insurers from refusing to cover patients with genetic diseases. Mr. Bush's proposals, made in a state that he lost to Al Gore in 2000 by fewer than 6,000 votes, offered more specifics on programs than the president included in the budget he sent to Congress on Feb. 4. They were similar to many proposals that Mr. Bush made during his presidential campaign, including a plan to double financing for the National Institutes of Health by the end of 2003.

headline.main: Bush Urges $300 Billion for Health Care Changes

docs.abstract: Pres Bush outlines $300 billion, 10-year health care plan he says will overhaul Medicare, offer discount card for elderly to buy prescription drugs and ban insurers from refusing to cover patients with genetic diseases, speech, Medical College of Wisconsin, Milwaukee; White House advisers say two proposals in plan are new, namely: expanded medical savings accounts to help people pay doctors' bills and improved tax credits for health coverage of uninsured, up to $3,000 per family; Bush says Medicare is antiquated and that its reform is central goal of administration (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. James E. McGreevey today unveiled his plan to eliminate the $2.9 billion gap in this year's budget without raising taxes -- by tapping into the state's various reserve funds, refinancing many state debts and imposing deep cuts in spending on health care, housing, school construction and environmental protection. Speaking before a special joint session of the New Jersey Legislature, Mr. McGreevey, a Democrat, reminded listeners that he had inherited the shortfall in the current $23 billion budget from the Republican administrations that preceded him, while urging a bipartisan effort to curb the state's profligate spending.

headline.main: McGreevey's Budget Calls for Deep Cuts

docs.abstract: Gov James McGreevey unveils plan to eliminate $2.9-billion gap in New Jersey's budget without raising taxes, by tappping into reserve funds, refinancing debts and imposing deep cuts in health care, housing and other spending; addresses Legislature, reminding members he inherited shortfall from Republican administrations; Republicans bristle and Sen John Bennett questions McGreevey's figures; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: More than 700 people turned out in Missoula over the weekend to show support for two lesbians whose home was gutted by fire several days after one of them, a professor of psychology, filed a discrimination lawsuit against the University of Montana here seeking health benefits for gay partners. Someone apparently broke into the home of the professor, Carla E. Grayson; her partner, Adrian Neff; and their infant son at 3 a.m., doused the floor with gasoline and set it afire, the police chief, Bob Reid, said. Jim Robbins (NYT)

headline.main: National Briefing | Rockies: Montana: Support For Fire Victims

docs.lead_paragraph: Ten months after Brandy French, 16, died of an overdose of the drug Ecstasy, law enforcement officials here and Brandy's father, Don French, are beginning to formally apportion blame. Mr. French, 36, who works in a food warehouse near here, is about to file a negligence lawsuit against some of the people with his daughter the night last May when she became fatally ill from the drug at a rock concert. He is not looking for revenge or money, Mr. French says, but accountability.

headline.main: Ecstasy Overdose Kills. Who Should Be Held to Account?

docs.abstract: Article on death of 16-year-old Brandy French, Pittsburgh, Pa, resident from overdose of drug Ecstasy after attending rock concert with friends; case may result welter of criminal charges; father weighs negligence lawsuit against friends who were with daughter night she died, and will sue insurance company of house where she was taken after becoming ill; says he is not seeking revenge, but accountability; incident described; photos (M)
